awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: COLLAB: An Intelligence-Driven Patient Care Approach to Reduce Medical Errors (I-CARE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Imagine that in the near future a patient needing surgery will swallow a small mobile robot that can autonomously perform the procedure without any external incisions or pain. Such robots have the potential to make state-of-the-art surgical concepts a reality by providing an unconstrained mobile platform to visualize, manipulate and surgically treat tissue. The project's strategy will also harness the excitement surrounding robotics and computer science, and leverage it with the investigators' exceptional infrastructure for education innovation and outreach to provide new, inspirational educational experiences for students. Finally, the project outcomes can broadly impact a number of other areas that would benefit from the developed novel methodologies, including search and rescue, construction and maintenance, and remote imaging, where the environment is dynamic or changes upon repeated inspection.

The goal of this project is to gain a fundamental understanding of the cognition and adaptation needs of an intelligence-driven patient care approach to reduce medical errors. Realizing such an intelligent physical system would allow for augmenting physician capabilities. If one considers an operating room of the future, one can imagine scenarios where data is collected from, and shared with, all medical personnel including the surgeon, the supporting medical technicians, and anesthesiologists. In addition, artificial intelligence could be harnessed to look for unseen patterns in patient care. This operating room of the future will only be possible by establishing a new paradigm that includes medical devices with embedded smart and autonomous features. Such an intelligent physical system would gather knowledge from support personnel, sensors and diagnostics, and interpret physician intent and provide suggestions and diagnostic feedback in real-time. To provide real-world evaluation of this approach, the project will focus on robotic capsule endoscopy, with an intent to have immediate impact in conventional gastroenterology procedures. In pursuit of this goal, this project addresses three research objectives: the first objective focuses on robotic capsule endoscopy perception and control; the second objective formulates the perception and diagnostic support requirements to augment physician performance; and the third objective integrates multimodal, multi-label, temporal data analytics for intelligent physician support.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Intelligence-driven patient Care Approach to Reduce medical Errors (I-CARE) project aimed to explore how smart technology could assist doctors in reducing medical errors and improving patient care. Imagine an "operating room of the future" where all medical personnel, from surgeons to anesthesiologists, have instant access to shared patient data. This information, along with artificial intelligence (AI), would help detect hidden patterns in patient care, potentially catching issues early. This vision of the future operating room is possible through an Intelligent Physical System (IPS) where medical devices are “smart” and able to offer real-time suggestions to the medical team.

For this project, we focused on a specific device called a robotic capsule endoscope (RCE), to be used in gastroenterology for examining the colon during a colonoscopy. Our team used a testing platform to explore how the RCE could navigate a synthetic (artificial) colon, find its way based only on video, and map its surroundings as it moved through. We even tested how well it would work in situations where the synthetic colon was shifting, simulating real-life conditions.

Our team developed strategies to help the RCE find its way through a complex environment using only video data, even if the environment moved or changed shape. We programmed the RCE to detect potentially cancerous growths (like polyps) and autonomously move toward them for a biopsy, demonstrating its potential for safer and more precise cancer screening. To see if our methods could be broadly useful, we applied them to several large, publicly available medical data sets. This helped us refine the technology to work on a wider range of cases.

In parallel work, using a data set from prostate cancer patients, we developed a machine learning system to predict treatment outcomes. By analyzing hundreds of patient cases and their imaging data, the system can offer predictions to assist doctors in decision-making processes, which may improve patient care by providing doctors with deeper insights.

The I-CARE project demonstrates that integrating smart technology in medical procedures has promising potential for the future. Using artificial intelligence and machine learning, these tools could eventually help medical professionals make more accurate and timely decisions, potentially transforming patient care and safety in procedures like colonoscopies and cancer treatment.
